When adding a new constructor param you should add a new equality group.
The pattern I use is to have one equality group per constructor param. The first one has two entries, as the second entry tests that two entries are the same if all params match. The other groups have one entry, with a single param changes. Hence for this class it would be:
    new EqualsTester()
        .addEqualityGroup(
            new ListTopics(Optional.of(SOME_LOCATION), true, true),
            new ListTopics(Optional.of(OTHER_LOCATION), true, true)  <-- tests `equals` returns true if all fields match.
        )
        .addEqualityGroup(
            new ListTopics(Optional.of(SOME_LOCATION), false, true), <-- tests `equals` returns false if `showAll` differs
        )
       .addEqualityGroup(
            new ListTopics(Optional.of(SOME_LOCATION), true, false), <-- tests `equals` returns false if `showExtended ` differs
        )
        .testEquals();

nodes.bodyText: This ignores property overrides associated with the request, right? I'm wondering about the situation where a user has a valid reason to INSERT INTO an topic marked as internal by default, issues the request and sees an error, and now wants to override the SYSTEM_INTERNAL_TOPICS_CONFIG config to enable their use case. If this code ignores the statement override (which I believe it does), then they can't achieve the override without setting the config at a server level and restarting the KSQL server, which feels unnecessarily heavy-weight.

I don't think we should allow users to override this setting at the console.

If it is an actual KSQL topic, e.g. the command topic, then we really don't want to allow them to produce to it!
If it is a topic the admin of the system has configured, via the new config, to be internal/read-only, then again, we should IMHO allow the CLI user to override this.
Agree with @big-andy-coates, we should not let users override the setting. If the KSQL admin decided to hide and make those topics read-only, then is up to the admin to change the setting.

That's fine, but can we be more explicit about it and add the property to https://github.com/confluentinc/ksql/blob/master/ksql-common/src/main/java/io/confluent/ksql/config/ImmutableProperties.java in that case? The current implementation of this PR is inconsistent in that it does not allow overrides for INSERT INTO but it does for INSERT VALUES.

I would still prefix this with ksql. as its a KSQL property. It doesn't really matter what system they're internal topics form.
Alternatively, you could call it ksql.read.only.topics.   The issue here is that the config isn't just controlling if a topic is read-only or not, but if it shows up in the Show topics output.
Can I make another suggestion?  How about we split this into two settings?

ksql.read.only.topics: controls which topics are read-only
ksql.hidden.topics: controls the topics which are hidden from show topics by default

Each setting is a list of regex patterns to match against.
This may give us a more flexible solution anyway.  Just a thought.

nodes.bodyText:
Great docs :)
We could even give them a link to docs on Java regex, for those not familiar, and add details of defaults and topics that KSQL always hidden.
A slightly reworded example is below.
Comma-separated list of topic that will be hidden. Entries in the list may be literal topic names or [Java regular expressions](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html). For example, `_confluent.*` will match any topic whose name starts with the `_confluent`).

Hidden topics will not visible when running the `SHOW TOPICS` command unless `SHOW ALL TOPICS` is used. 

The default value hides known system topics from Kafka and Confluent products.

KSQL also marks its own internal topics as hidden. This is not controlled by this config.

As above, an example being:
Comma-separated list of topic that will be treated as read-only. Entries in the list may be literal topic names or [Java regular expressions](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html). For example, `_confluent.*` will match any topic whose name starts with the `_confluent`).

Read-only topics cannot be modified by any KSQL command.

The default value marks known system topics from Kafka and Confluent products as read-only.

KSQL also marks its own internal topics as read-only. This is not controlled by this config.

Still not convinced this is the right way to create the processing log config. This is not how it's created at the moment.
e.g. can the processing log config ever have a password in it? In which case this 'withSecretsObfuscated` would fail.
e.g. can the ksqlConfig passed in here include overrides users have supplied in the CLI?
At the moment, the ProcessingLogConfig is created in one place and then injected / passed to where it is needed. IMHO this is a better pattern than creating it in multiple places, when ever needed: the single instance pattern ensures we're using the same config everywhere.
Hence, I urge you to change the code so that we're passing down the ProcessorLogConfig to where its needed, ideally injecting it into constructors, rather than passing it as an argument of other methods, with it finally being passed as a separate constructor argument here.
Did you see Vic's comment about adding the config(s) to the list of immutable configs? #4322 (comment)

Rather than having this error checking here, it would be cleaner to check for invalid regular expressions using a Validator on the config itself.
